m_DescList: When writing regular expressions, we typically use <color=#AB2800>.</color> to represent "any" character.
<color=#AB2800>.</color>  Matches any single character except a newline
<color=#AB2800>\.</color>  Matches only a decimal point
<color=#3c3cff>123.456</color>
For example, using <color=#AB2800>\..</color> to match the above example:
The first <color=#AB2800>\.</color> is interpreted as "match only a decimal point"
The second <color=#AB2800>.</color> is interpreted as "any" character
<color=#3c3cff>123.456</color> returns
<color=#666666>123</color><color=#3c3cff>.4</color><color=#666666>56</color>
<color=#3c3cff>(x3x)</color>
For example, using <color=#AB2800>3..</color> to match the above example:
The first <color=#AB2800>3</color> is interpreted as "the digit 3"
The second and third <color=#AB2800>.</color> are interpreted as "any" characters
<color=#3c3cff>(x3x)</color> returns 3x
<color=#666666>(x</color><color=#3c3cff>3x)</color>
Now, we want to match as many arbitrary characters as possible following the digit 1.
In this test, the target string has the following characteristics:
<color=#3c3cff>1</color>    Contains at least one digit 1
<color=#3c3cff>.</color>     Followed by arbitrary characters of varying length
Please construct a regular expression that passes all tests on the right.
